content.body: jcranmer, what sort of protocol I/O are you doing in browsers?
mcarter: it's not something in a browser
it's something in JS
IMAP, NNTP, SMTP, POP, managesieve, probably IRC in the future as well
jcranmer, are these clients?
mcarter: servers, actually
jcranmer, I don't suppose your'e doing any client work at all?
mcarter: I am
jcranmer, is any of this open source by any chance?
mcarter:
yep
http://mxr.mozilla.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/test/fakeserver/
jcranmer, http://www.js.io/svn/js.io/trunk/protocols/irc/irc2.js (irc client implementation, MIT licensed, if you need it)
jcranmer, what license is your code?
MPL, I think
jcranmer, do you mind if I send you a private chat?
MPL,GPL, LGPL tri-licensed to be precise
mcarter: np
hsivonen: you around?
anyone know where to get stats on which % of documents have standards-mode doctypes?

as of january, in a scan of about three billion documents biased against spam sites and towards more frequently visited and modified sites, full standards was 10%, almost standards was 40%, and quirks was 50%.
thanks
that's the most recent data i've collected, but if you want updated numbers i can set another scan up
no, that's fine thanks
k

i once tried to do a scan that bucketed sites on a per-year basis based on last-modified headers, which showed an increase in standards mode doctype and a much more significant increase in almost standards mode doctypes
but the data is so noisy that it's hard to do good studies based on that
the year data, that is
(e.g. there as many pages from 2009 today as from 1994)
(and far more from 2050 and 1970 than from 1998, iirc)
hehe
Hixie: "Your TV doesn't size to fit the video data." -- no, but my media players on the computer do
Hixie, "we shouldn't pick a codec that requires that subtitles be burnt in." - It's the container format that matters for that, not the video codec
http://developer.mozilla.org/web-tech/2008/10/13/mozafterpaint/
annevk3: around?
sort of
annevk3: How many entities do you intend to define in XML5?
I was planning on having the exact same list as HTML5 (though always require a semicolon)
annevk3: k
(I realized that behaviour of non-validating XML processors when finding unknown entities in undefined in XML 1.0 in cases)
gsnedders: the XML processor behavior is defined: report to application
gsnedders: it's even part of the main SAX interface
hsivonen, it's not clear whether it's a fatal error though
it's not fatal.
checks the spec
annevk3: the spec doesn't make it an error of any kind, so it is not a fatal error
yet it's fatal in some implementations
e.g. Gecko
the reason why it is fatal in Gecko is that Gecko's entity resolver tricks expat into thinking that expat has seen all external entities
if the entity resolver weren't tricking expat, it wouldn't be fatal
even if Gecko weren't tricking expat like this and expat reported the skipped entity to the application, the application could opt to do fatal stuff with that information
Why is Gecko tricking expat like this?
(I'm not trying to say that Gecko's behavior here is good. Just that it's not an XML processor bug and that the behavior taken as a whole is not non-conforming)
Philip`: expat doesn't have a mode where it would read certain DTDs
Philip`: it either wants to read all or none
Philip`: Gecko wants it to read some
Philip`: so when Gecko doesn't want it to read a DTD, the entity resolver resolves unwanted DTDs to a zero-length stream
which from the point of view of the XML spec is different from not trying to resolve at all
Ah, right
one might argue that a better fix would have been extending the entity resolver interface to have an "I don't want to resolve this" return value
I don't particularly care what browsers do there for now

You should write some web-based platform-independent photo editing/management software and then it wouldn't be a problem
Philip`: No.

It's much easier if you simply relax your definition of "good"
I don't really want to dual-boot either, because then I have eternal fun debating size of partitions
and then you could use Gimp or Krita or whatever
Resizing partitions isn't really that hard
at least on Linux (using LVM), and probably on Windows (using magical features of NTFS that must surely exist though I have no idea how to enable them)
It's annoying, though
(I have no idea how partitioning works in OS X; I just drag the slidey bar and pray that it's not going to clobber all my data)
is there a slidey bar in OS X these days?
Philip`: It won't let me drag it here :(
hsivonen: Yes, in the Disk Utility or whatever it's called
http://www.creativetechs.com/iq/tip_images/DiskUtility-Resize.gif
Philip`: oh. I hadn't noticed.
Philip`: I can't grow one partition (HFS+) and shrink another (NTFS) in there :(
http://forum.notebookreview.com/showpost.php?p=4003347&postcount=30 — that doesn't make me want to use Ubuntu
gsnedders: That's probably because OS X doesn't understand how to shrink NTFS - I guess you'd have to do it via Windows (or a third-party tool) instead
gsnedders: (I've only used it once, to shrink an HFS+ partition and create a new NTFS one (alongside the existing NTFS one created by Boot Camp))
Philip`: Ah, I just used the CLI to do that :)

(Then I used the magic of Vista's NTFS symlinks to move my Steam games folder onto the new partition without having to modify or move or reinstall anything else, and it actually worked, which was nice)

not thought of that :)
takkaria: URL?
hsivonen: http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/2008/09/23-minutes#item06
I thought there was a detailed review of the HTML5 sectioning and heading elements linked to from this channel recently, but I can't find it in the logs or my history
any ideas?
it was on a blog
BenMillard, it's linked from the latest this week in HTML5
iirc
annevk3, you're a genius!
pats annevk3 on the back.
bookmarks the page.
takkaria, I have the feeling "we"'re quite aligned with the TAG actually; it seems that sometimes they misunderstand HTML5 and value a different approach to spec writing
but that is mostly an editorial issue and should therefore not cause much conflict
the idea that, e.g. you can split the parsing section into "clean" and "not clean" and have them in seperate specs is mad, though
it kind of depends on what they mean with "clean", "not clean", and "parsing" :)
because processors will have to implement "not clean", and having them in seperate specs will only create duplication, confusion, and faulty implementation
if by "clean" they mean writing and by "not clean" whatever browsers have to do, we'd be nearly there
except that currently it's two separate sections rather than two separate specifications
I guess.  I get the impression they wouldn't be satisfied with an authoring guide and a specification though
I wasn't talking about an authoring guide, I was talking about section 8.1
they don't like the language specification including enough detail to write a browser with, afaict
mm
seems kind of weird for the W3C to encourage specs that browsers can't interoperably implement :)
maybe the F2F next week with the TAG will help

I guess some of this comes down to my philosophy of language... the meaning of a language found in how the language is used.  to try and specify the meaning of something whilst ignoring how it's used seems about the most futile and unrewarding task one can set oneself
takkaria: ah. old minutes. I wondered if there were new ones
hasn't been around much since the end of September, so they're new to me :)
takkaria: my story is that the "Writing" section is the clean section for parsing
Every time I search for things about java, I find articles from 2004 or older
annevk3: the "clean" parsing spec could be a view of the spec proper with the steps after any parse error instead says "Abort."

Says there's no reason to manually use stringbuffer since the JVM will automatically make one for most simple cases, makes sense. But on the other hand, stringbuffer is synced so has overhead compared to stringbuilder in single-threaded uses.

Dashiva: Expensive in terms of execution time? That can vary by several orders of magnitude in a single run of the program, so it's kind of impossible to give an answer
The relative costs, not absolute
The relative costs can vary by several orders of magnitude

e.g. I guess a program would spend relatively more time doing arithmetic when it starts up, but that'll all get JITted to be really fast and it'll end up spending more time chasing pointers and getting cache misses or whatever
You're getting closer

and you have to worry about e.g. garbage collection, where allocating memory has approximately zero immediate cost (since it might just be incrementing a pointer) but can have a much more significant longer-term cost
so I'm not sure what kind of information exists that would be helpful for what you're asking for, and I'm not even sure what you're asking for :-)
Sure the information exists, that's how you optimize compilers :)
If you're targetting JVM bytecode, you don't optimise your compiler, since that's the JVM's job :-)
Pushing an immediate operand and calling a virtual function aren't exactly on the same complexity level
The JVM might inline that virtual function call so it has no cost at all
Not very virtual then
The JVM can be sure that it's exactly equivalent to if it were virtual
e.g. if it knows the object is of type T and no class exists that extends T, then it could directly call T's method without the virtual indirection
And pushing an operand onto the stack doesn't have a well-defined cost either, because it'll all get translated into register-based code
Now suppose I know what kind of code I'm writing, and I know that virtual call is very virtual indeed
I suppose so
Now what? :-)
I'm proposing that it will be more expensive than a push :)
But a push doesn't have a well-defined cost :-p
Sure, but good job doing a function call without at least one push :P

That's easy - you just specialise the function which does that function call, on the type of the object you're calling virtually, and then the function call itself is no longer virtual and can be inlined quite happily and maybe won't have any cost at all :-)
whereas maybe that one push will force the JITter to spill registers and it'll slow the whole method horribly
You'd rather abuse the poor cache with duplicate code, shame on you
Maybe most of the duplicates almost never get executed
Anyway, I've got way more cache than I used to have RAM just a few years ago ;-)
and I would say that's more than I used to have disk space a few years before that, but I think I'd be lying
I do have more RAM than I had disk space
I have that, I just don't have more cache :-(
I suppose it depends on what level cahce you count
I count the bigger one because it sounds more impressive
Those are like 4-8 MB now, aren't they?
I have 4MB, presumably shared between all the cores
Then again, I have memories of an apple II which I'm not even sure had a harddisk
Oh, looks like it's 4MB shared between two cores, so my quad-core one must have 8MB total
So, plenty of space to store duplicated code!
